frameDefinitions: An Agent displays a Characteristic of a Standard in his or her own way of behaving.
These words relate to the relative ordering of two events or times.
A member or members of a Class have just been  mentioned or are present in the discourse setting and now a different instance  (or group of instances) of the same class is referred to.
Two or more distinct entities, which may be concrete or abstract objects or types, are characterized as being similar to each other.

This frame is concerned with the idea that people (Participant_1, Participant_2, or Participants) participate in an organized, rule-governed activity (the Competition) in order to achieve some advantageous outcome (often the Prize).
The words in this frame describe situations in which a Perpetrator forcibly seizes control over a Victim's Vehicle to gain some end.  ''
frameExamples: I guessed he was trying to <t>imitate</t> the movements of a skier
<t>After</t> she arrived , she laid out her papers on the desk.
My husband left me for <t>another</t> woman -- and now wants to get back together again!

A mulberry is very <t>similar</t> in shape
to a loganberry
French farmers have <t>hijacked</t> a lorry and destroyed its load of strawberries.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Agent</fen> is the person that borrows a <fen>Characteristic</fen> behavior from a <fen>Standard</fen>.
The <fen>Characteristic</fen> is a behavior or property that the <fen>Standard</fen> possesses and which the <fen>Agent</fen> adopts in his or her own behavior.
The <fen>Standard</fen> is the entity that exhibits a certain <fen>Characteristic</fen> that the <fen>Agent</fen> models their own behavior on.
The time at which the imitation occurs.
The location where the <fen>Agent</fen> imitates some entity which acts as a <fen>Standard</fen>.

The <fen>Focal_occasion</fen> is the event which is  being located in time with respect to some other event: The <fen>Focal_occasion</fen> is profiled, in contrast to the <fen>Landmark_occasion</fen>, which is backgrounded.
The <fen>Landmark_occasion</fen> is the event  with respect to which the <fen>Focal_occasion</fen> is located.
The <fen>Focal_participant</fen> is the participant in the <fen>Focal_occasion</fen> which is profiled as being in a relation of relative time to the <fen>Landmark_occasion</fen>.
The general category of entity which has been referred to.
The instance of the <fen>Class</fen> that is added to the <fen>Initial_set</fen> of entities in the <fen>Class</fen>.
The previously mentioned group of entities of the <fen>Class</fen>.
This role marks constituents that express the set of objects or types whose similarity is at issue.

When there is an asymmetry, <fen>Entity_1</fen> is the entity characterized by its similarity to <fen>Entity_2</fen>, whose characteristics are assumed to be known.  <fen>Entity_1</fen> is often an external argument.

When the <fen>Entities</fen> are expressed separately, <fen>Entity_2</fen> is the one whose characteristics are assumed to be known; it serves as a basis for establishing characteristics of <fen>Entity_1</fen>.
This role marks constituents which express a property in respect to which the similarity of the entities is assessed.
A fact about <fen>Entity_1</fen> or the <fen>Entities</fen> that reveals how <fen>Entity_1</fen> is the same or different from other entities.  (Note the contrast with 'as to'.)
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the similarity occurs or exists.
The Place is the general area in which similarity occurs or exists
This role identifies the first (or only) participant in a competition.
This role identifies the second participant in a competition.
This role is used for plural NP participants in a competition.
This role is used for the name of the competition.
The period of time when the <fen>Competition</fen> occurs.

Where the event takes place. 
A constituent tagged as <fen>Place</fen> may require annotation on a secondary FE-layer.
This is the person (or other agent) who forcibly seizes control over a vehicle to gain some end.
This is the means of transportation which gets under the control of the perpetrator. Example: The terrorists hijacked <fex name='Vehicle'>the plane</fex>.
This role describes the people that are suffering as a result of the <fen>Perpetrator</fen>'s action.
When the event occurs.
Where the event takes place.
listRoleExamples: Mimic Snotlings do n't really think for themselves, <fex>they</fex> merely mimic the actions of Orcs and Goblins around them.
They were all mimicking <fex>my accent</fex>.
The singer says Gwen has copied <fex>her</fex> in many different ways.
<fex>Hours of eating and drinking</fex> followed the wedding ceremony.
Hours of eating and drinking followed <fex>the wedding ceremony</fex>.
<fex>We</fex> were late for dinner.
My Husband left me for another <fex>man</fex>!
There was <fex><t>another</t> power outage</fex> today.
A further five incursions <fex>over and above those noted for 1995</fex> took place in the first three months of 1996.
<fex>The two painters</fex> were alike in being unable to draw acceptably .
In the first phase <fex>Barthes's approach</fex> has similarities to that of Levi-Strauss.
The results of Method 2 show remarkable similarity <fex>to those obtained by Method 1</fex>
The disc announced Friday is <fex>physically</fex> similar to current music CDs
His presidency was different <fex>in that it offered a way forward for the common man</fex> .
<fex>Jo</fex> played the lottery every day.
Jo played <fex>Leslie</fex> at tennis.
<fex>Jo and Leslie</fex> played tennis.
Jo played <fex>in the foosball tournament</fex>
First layer: John's first competition <fex>at Wimbledon</fex> astonished the crowd.
The rebels skyjacked a plane <fex>with 89 passangers</fex>.
